Developing the stable CoCu catalysts for higher alcohol (HA) synthesis is hindered by the dynamic evolution of complex active sites. Herein, a potassium (K)-modified strategy was proposed to address these issues. The regulating effect of K on Co and Cu sites was comprehensively explored. K doping not only enhanced the metal dispersion, but also regulated the Co0/Coδ⁺ ratio and provided the hydroxyl groups (OH*). The enhanced metal dispersion was ascribed to the improved electrical conductivity, strengthening the synergistic effect. The Co0 proportion of Cu-rich catalysts increased, while it decreased over Co-rich catalysts. The K-induced OH* enhanced CO adsorption ability of Cu species, improving HA selectivity and restraining the aggregation of Cu species. The higher Co0 proportion mitigated the impact of Co evolution. Hence, K doping Cu-rich catalysts boosted total alcohol selectivity from 9.1 % to 17.4 %, reduced methanol fraction from 61.7 % to 37.1 %, and achieved excellent stability during 100 h test. Graphical Abstract Keywords Higher alcohol Potassium Active site regulation CoCu catalysts Reaction stability Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Higher alcohols (HA), a mixture of C2 + alcohols, play an irreplaceable role in various fields, including biofuels, fine chemicals, pharmaceuticals, and advanced material [1]. The catalytic conversion of syngas (CO+H₂) to HA represents a promising route for the efficient utilization of carbon resources derived from coal, natural gas, or biomass. This process is particularly attractive due to its potential for carbon neutrality and contribution to a circular carbon economy [2,3]. Large amounts of researchers have made significant efforts and achieved remarkable progress in developing efficient catalysts for HA synthesis. Among these systems, CoCu catalysts are considered as one of the most promising candidates owing to its excellent catalytic performance and rich reservoirs [4]. Generally, the synergic effect of Co and Cu plays the key role in this process, in which Co is responsible for CO dissociative adsorption and carbon chain growth, while Cu is responsible for CO non-dissociative adsorption and CO insertion [5]. A large number of theoretical and experimental results have demonstrated that shortening the distance between Co and Cu is an efficient strategy to achieve high yields of HA. Based on this, the CoCu alloy and core-shell particles are proposed as efficient active sites for HA synthesis [6,7]. Moreover, Prieto et al. [6] revealed that the content of CoCu alloy had the tight relationship with the yield of HA. However, this process still faces the formidable obstacles owing to its insufficient reaction stability, which is primarily attributed to the limited miscibility and the different surface energies between Co and Cu [8]. Researches focused on stability property confirmed that the intimately contacted Co and Cu species were not stable during the reaction [9–11]. For example, Yang et al. [12] found that the aggregation of Cu species and the evolution of Co species (Co2C formation) were occurred from alloy particles. Thus, to enhance the reaction stability, a key factor lies in suppressing the evolution of the Co and Cu species. After years of research, the applications of supports and promoters in CoCu catalysts have been recognized as an effective strategy to enhance the reaction stability. KIT-6, a mesoporous silica material, is commonly used as a catalyst support due to its uniform pore structure, large pore size, and high surface area [13]. Li et al. [8,14] proposed that the confinement effect of KIT-6 had the positive effect on improving the reaction stability and the CoCu alloy phase was maintained during 200 h test. However, the evolution of the isolated Cu and the Coδ⁺ species in their work was rarely discussed. Doping with promoters is also beneficial for the regulation of active sites, thereby improving the reaction stability. Potassium (K), as one of the effective promoters, has been evidenced to be instrumental in enhancing bimetal dispersion and adjusting Co0/Coδ+ ratio [15–17]. Xu et al. [18] stated that K enhanced the interaction between Cu species and support, preventing excessive reduction or aggregation under reduction conditions. Yao et al. [19] pointed out that K addition could stabilize Cu⁰ by adjusting its electronic structure, thus reducing aggregation and sintering. Ao et al. [20] claimed that the modification of K could adjust Co0/Coδ⁺ ratio and had a significant impact on the catalytic performance. Besides, a large number of researchers have also confirmed that the content of K greatly influenced the catalytic performance, in which the excessive K might overly cover the catalyst surface and the appropriate amount of K was around 1 % [21,22]. Consequently, the appropriate amount of K modified CoCu/KIT-6 catalysts was a promising approach for constructing the highly stable CoCu catalysts. However, the mechanism remains unclear due to the complexity of its catalytic environment [23]. For example, in addition to the intimately contacted Co and Cu species, numerous studies have reported the presence of isolated Cu and unsaturated Co species [24,25], indicating that both the aggregation of Cu and the evolution of Co could occur on all active sites. Regarding the complex catalytic environment of the catalysts, our previous works proposed the change of alcohol distribution could reflect the evolution of active sites by adjusting the metal proximity, providing a convenient way to monitor the changes in active sites [26]. Moreover, owing to the uniform pore structure of KIT-6, the active sites on the phase-separated catalysts could be divided to Co and Cu species, with no obvious CoCu particles detected, thereby facilitating the study of individual active sites [26]. Motivated by the above analysis, the addition of K on the phase-separated CoCu catalysts was favored to elucidate the regulating effect of K on restraining the evolution of Co and Cu species, providing a valuable methodology for developing highly stable CoCu catalysts. Nevertheless, there are few reports about the effect of K on the reaction stability for HA synthesis over CoCu catalysts. Herein, the K-modified strategy was proposed to stabilize Co and Cu species by doping 1 % K into phase-separated CoCu catalysts with tunable Co/Cu ratio via the incipient wetness method. The prepared K-doping catalysts exhibited an excellent reaction stability compared to K-free catalysts. The catalytic performance and structural characterization results indicated that K-doping had significant regulating effect on both Co and Cu species. The unique structure and physicochemical properties of K-doped catalyst were discussed in detail to further investigate the regulate effect of K. In addition, the evolution of both Co and Cu species during the reaction was investigated by alcohol distribution analyze, XPS and TEM characterization. This work provided a comprehensive understanding of the role of K doping in stabilizing CoCu catalysts and offered practical insights for designing efficient and stable catalysts for industrial applications. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of the catalyst The CoxCu5-x/KIT-6 catalysts were prepared in our previous work [26] and the details were shown in the Supplementary material. 2.0 g CoxCu5-x/KIT-6 catalysts was first pretreated in vacuum at 60 °C overnight. Certain amounts of K2CO3 were dissolved in deionized water and stirred for 2 h. Then the homogeneous solution was mixed with CoxCu5-x/KIT-6 catalysts and then stirred for 1 h at room temperature. After that, the mixture was dried 120 °C for 5 h and then calcined in air at 400 °C for 6 h. The mass of K loading was about 1 wt%. The as-prepared catalysts were denoted as K-CoxCu5-x/KIT-6 (x = 0, 1, 3, and 4). 2.2 Characterization of the catalyst The N2 absorption-desorption characterization was conducted on a Micromeritics ASAP-2020 instrument (USA). The catalysts were pretreated at 200 °C for 4 h. The textural properties were calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. X-ray Diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed with a Rigaku D/MAX-2700 diffractometer (Japan) over a 2θ range of 10–80 °, with a scan rate of 4 °/min, operating at 100 mA and 40 kV using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.1541 Å). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on an ESCALAB 250 XPS instrument (USA), utilizing monochromatic Al Kα radiation (hν = 1486.6 eV) under a base pressure of 7.0 × 108 Pa, with an energy of 30 eV and a step size of 0.1 eV. The binding energy of C1s (284.6 eV) was used to correct the binding energies. The temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) was conducted on a TP-5080 adsorption analyzer. The samples were first reduced at 400 ºC in H2/He mixture (10 vol% H2) for 2 h and then exposed into CO2 atmosphere at 50 ºC for 1 h. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were performed using a CHI660e electrochemical workstation, covering a frequency range from 0.01 to 100000 Hz. The results of particle size distribution and the morphology of samples were conducted by Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (JEM-2100F, Japan). The temperature-programmed reduction of H2 (H2-TPR) was conducted on TP-5000 instrument. The samples were first pretreated in He (30 mL/min) at 150 ºC for 30 min. After cooling to room temperature, the samples were exposed into 5 vol% H2/N2 mixture and heated to 900 ºC (10 ºC/min). 2.2.1 Evaluation of the catalysts The catalyst performance was conducted in a fixed bed microreactor with stainless steel tubular, in which the diameter and length were 8 mm and 240 mm, respectively. The catalyst (1 g, 40–60 mesh) diluted with the quartz beads (1 g, 40–60 mesh) was loaded into reaction tube (the constant-temperature region). The samples were first in-situ reduced at 400 °C (reduction conditions: 30 % H2/N2, 90 mL/min, atmospheric pressure, 3 h). After the temperature was reduced to 270 °C, the reaction atmosphere (H2/CO= 2:1, 75 mL/min) was introduced to the reactor. Then, the reaction pressure was adjusted to 3.0 MPa. During the reaction, the tail gas was analyzed online using gas chromatography (GC-950) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector and a flame ionization detector. The carbon monoxide (CO), methane (CH4), and carbon dioxide (CO2) were detected by the carbon molecular sieve column (TDX-01), while the organic gas products (hydrocarbons and alcohols) were detected by the capillary column (HP-PLOT/Q). Another GC-950 instrument equipped with a flame ionization detector was employed to analyze offline the liquid products collected from the cold trap, in which the capillary column (HP-INNOWAX) and the capillary column (DB-5MS UI) were used to detect alcohols and hydrocarbons, respectively. CO conversion (SCO), product selectivity (Si) and chain growth probability factor (α) were calculated by following equations: (1) X C O = ∑ n i ( g ) + ∑ n i ( l ) n ( C O ) i n × 100 % (2) S i = n i ( g ) + n i ( l ) ∑ n i ( g ) + ∑ n i ( l ) × 100 % (3) ln ( w n n ) = nlnα + constant In Eq. (1) and Eq. (2), where ni referred to the molar amounts of carbon atoms of the products, while g and l referred to gas and liquid product, respectively. In Eq. (3), the Wn referred to the mass fraction of each alcohol and α referred to and the chain growth probability factor, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of catalysts The catalytic performance of K-doped CoxCu5-x/KIT-6 was shown in Table S1. With the doping of K, the alcohol selectivity and the HA fraction of all the catalysts were increased. Especially, the maximum enhancement in catalytic performance occurred over Cu-rich catalysts (Co:Cu=1:4), in which the alcohol selectivity was improved from 9.1 % to 17.4 % and the methanol fraction was decreased from 61.7 % to 37.1 %. Moreover, the CO2 selectivity of the K-doped catalysts was increased compared to the K-free catalysts. It was reported that the existence of alkali species would boost the reactivity of the water-gas shift process (WGS) [27]. Nevertheless, K doping had a different effect on the CO conversion over different Co/Cu ratio. To clearly observe the trend, the difference value of CO conversion between the K-doped and K-free catalysts was exhibited in Fig. 1. Obviously, with the doping of K, the CO conversion was increased over the Cu-rich catalysts, while the opposite trend occurred on Co-rich catalysts. Ao et al. [20] investigated the K doping effect on the Co-Ni-Cu catalysts in HA synthesis and demonstrated that K doping restrained the reduction degree of Co species, decreasing the CO conversion. It was widely believed that Co0 species were primarily responsible for CO dissociative adsorption and the carbon chain growth process. Moreover, the conversion of CO and the capability for carbon chain growth were positively correlated with the content of Co0 [28]. The difference in CO conversion implied that the regulating effect of K on Co0/Coδ⁺ ratio varied with the Co/Cu ratio. Meanwhile, the decreased CO conversion and methanol fraction over K-doped Co-rich catalysts suggested that K doping could regulate other active sites on the CoCu catalysts. 3.2 Structure properties of K-doped CoxCu5-x/KIT-6 catalysts 3.2.1 N2 absorption-desorption characterization The N2 absorption-desorption characterization was conducted to study the textural properties of K-doped catalysts. All the catalyst exhibited the IV isotherms type [29] (Figure S1a). Compared with the K-free catalysts, the location of the adsorption-desorption isotherms and the H1 hysteresis loop remained largely the same, indicating that the mesoporous structure of the catalysts was maintained [30,31]. Table S2 summarized the textural properties of K-doped catalysts. The surface area, pore volume and pore size of all the samples were decreased compared with K-free catalysts, indicating that the K was successfully loaded on the catalysts [32]. However, K doping enriched the pore size distribution within the 0–5 nm range, which was attributed to the formation of the microporous structure (Figure S1b). Generally, particles encapsulated within the channels of the support occupied the pore space, thereby decreasing the pore volume and the surface area [32,33]. Therefore, the decreased textural properties and the formation of microporous structure indicated that some metal particles were encapsulated into the channels of KIT-6 with the addition of K. 3.2.2 XRD characterization The XRD patterns for the calcined and reduced catalysts were exhibited in Fig. 2 and the crystallite sizes of Cu and Co species were summarized in Table 1. For the calcined catalysts (Fig. 2a), the diffraction peaks at 35.5°, 38.0° and 48.7° were assigned to the crystalline planes of CuO phase, and the peaks at 31.3° and 36.8° were assigned to Co3O4. The diffraction peaks of K were hardly detected, which might result from their low concentrations and high dispersion. Besides, the intensities of the characteristic peaks for K-doped catalysts were found to be similar with the K-free catalysts, indicating that K had no obvious effect on the crystallite structure of CoCu catalysts. For the reduced catalysts (Fig. 2b), the diffraction peaks were detected at 34.1°, 43.1° and 44.2°, which could be attributed to CoO, Cu0 and Co0, respectively. Compared with K-free catalysts, the peaks of K-doped catalysts became broader and the crystallite size of Cu was smaller, indicating that K doping improved the metal dispersion during the reduction process. 3.2.3 XPS characterization The XPS characterization was employed to analyze the surface concentration of the catalysts ( Fig. 3), and the results were listed in Table 2. The 2p 3/2 binding energy (BE) of Cu and Co for all the samples were around 932.1–932.5 eV and 781.0–781.9 eV, respectively, suggesting that the Cu2+ and the Co3+ were reduced to the low valence species [34]. From Table 2, the BE of Cu 2p 3/2 shifted to higher values with the doping of K. For the Co 2p 3/2 , the BE of Co3Cu2/KIT-6 and Co4Cu1/KIT-6 was lower than the K-doped catalysts, while the opposite trend was occurred on Co1Cu4/KIT-6. Generally, the particle size, the interaction effect and the reduction degree of bimetallic affected the chemical environments, thereby altering the position of BE [35]. The higher Cu 2p 3/2 BE of K-doped catalysts ascribed to smaller particle size of Cu and the stronger synergistic effect between Cu and Co, for which the smaller Cu particles exhibited the stronger surface effects and the adjacent Co species altered the surface electronic structure of Cu, leading to a higher shift in the BE position [36]. The variations in Co 2p 3/2 BE attributed to the differences in the reduction degree of Co species. As Co species were reduced, the increased electron density and the enhanced shielding effect resulted in a decrease in BE [28]. The surface content of Co species was listed in Table 2. As reported, the BE position of Co 2p located at 778.5, 780.7 and 782.0 eV could be attributed to Co0, CoO and Co-O-Si species [37,38]. For Cu-rich catalysts (Co/Cu=1:4), the doping of K promoted the reduction degree of Co, the concentration of Co0 increased from 2.5 % to 5.8 %, while for Co-rich catalysts, the concentration of Co0 was decreased. The O 1 s spectra of the catalysts was shown in Fig. 3c. The peak located between 529.0 and 535.0 eV corresponding to the O2- ions in the lattice. With the addition of K, the binding energy peaks of all the catalysts shifted towards higher energy, which was mainly related to the hydroxyl groups, resulting from the interaction between the alkali metal cations and the oxygen anions [39]. 3.2.4 CO2-TPD characterization The surface basicity was investigated through the CO2-TPD characterization. As shown in Fig. 4, a broad peak at 100–200 °C was exist for all the samples, which was assigned to the adsorbed CO2 on the weakly basic sites. With the doping of K, the peak moved to a higher temperature, and the area became broader, indicating that K-doped catalysts had more basic sites than K-free catalysts. It was proved that the surface basicity change of K-doped catalysts was mainly ascribed to the hydroxyl group (-OH), where the K could interact with H2O to form more hydroxyl groups [40]. Consequently, the CO2-TPD results demonstrated that K doping could provide more hydroxyl groups. Based on the above characterization results, the K promoter played a versatile role in CoCu catalysts. K doping effectively regulated the crystallite size of Cu during the reduction process and the valence ratio of Co species, as well as introduced the hydroxyl group. 3.2.5 Regulating effect of K on the active sites To further elucidate the regulating effect of K on the active sites, comprehensive characterization techniques including EIS, TEM, H2-TPR and in situ CO DRIFT were performed. Fig. 5 displayed the bode plots of K-doped and K-free catalysts. Upon K doping, the impedance magnitude was lower than the K-free catalysts, indicating that K improved the electron-transferring property of the catalysts. Typically, the electron-transferring property had a significant effect on the particles size by modifying the nucleation and growth processes [41]. The improved electron-transferring property inhibited the aggregation of Cu species during the reduction process, which aligned with the XRD and XPS findings. Figs. 6a, 6b and 6c displayed the TEM results of K-Co1Cu4/KIT-6. Compared with Co1Cu4/KIT-6 [26], K doping restrained the aggregation of Cu, resulting in relatively narrow particle distribution (from 3–30 nm to 2–20 nm). The elemental mapping image (Fig. 6c) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) data further confirmed that K doping enhanced the metal dispersion. Besides, some adjacent nanoparticles in the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of the K-Co1Cu4/KIT-6 catalyst (Fig. 6d) displayed clear interlayer spacings of 0.209 nm and 0.205 nm, which were attributed to the lattice planes of Cu0 and Co0, respectively [42]. The above results indicated that Co and Cu species were in close proximity with the doping of K. The ASF plots of hydrocarbons and alcohols were fitted in Figure S2. Obviously, the carbon distribution of both alcohol and hydrocarbon deviated from the typical ASF laws. Considering the competitive relationship between HA and hydrocarbon synthesis, the formed CxHy* on Co0 could react with CO* and H* , forming the HA and hydrocarbon, respectively [43]. The deviated alcohol distribution was caused by the co-existence of Cu-rich and Co-rich active sites on the surface of catalysts [26]. As reported, the Co/Cu ratio had a significant effect on the CO insertion ability [35]. Thus, the carbon distribution of the hydrocarbon deviated from the typical ASF laws. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 7, the difference in the values of α(C4-C6) and α(C1-C3) for both hydrocarbon and alcohol decreased with the doping of K, further confirming that K improved the metal dispersion of the catalysts. Fig. 8 displayed the H2-TPR profiles of the K-doped and K-free catalysts. As shown in Fig. 8a, the profiles of all the samples were classified into two area: low temperature area and high temperature. For Cu/KIT-6, two reduction peaks were observed in low temperature area, which could attributed to the bulk CuO and highly dispersed CuO phase [44], and no obvious peak was detected in high temperature area. For Co/KIT-6, two reduction peaks were existed in low temperatur area and a broad peak were observed in high temperature, which could be assigned to the reduction of Co3O4 to Co0 and Co-O-Si to Co0 [42], respectively. For K-doped catalysts, the position of peaks shifted to higher temperature compared with K-free catalysts. From the basic understanding of CoxCu5-x/catalysts, the phase-separated structure resulted in the complex composte distribution on the catalyst. Thus, all the composte should be considered in the analyze of TPR results. The peak fitting results of H2-TPR were shown in Fig. 8b. For Cu-rich catalysts (Co/Cu=1:4), the peak at low temperature area could be divided into two peaks, representing for the reduction behavior of (bulk CuO to Cu0) (named as Ⅰ) and (highly dispersed CuO to Cu0+Co3O4 to Co0) (named as Ⅱ), respectively. With the doping of K, the proportion of Ⅰ peak was decreased from 33.8 % to 20.7 % and the proportion of Ⅱ peak was increased from 47.0 % to 60.9 %. The XRD and EIS results confirmed that the crystallite size of Cu was decreased during the reduction process due to the strong interaction between K and Cu, which was the main reason for the decreased Ⅰ peak. The increased Ⅱ peak indicated that the reduction degree of Co species was improved, suggesting that the hydrogen spillover occurred between Co and Cu owing to the stronger synergistic effect between Co and Cu with the addition of K. For Co-rich catalysts (Co/Cu=3:2 and 4:1), the peak at around 300 °C was observed and could be assigned to the reduction behavior of (Co2+ to Co0) (named as Ⅲ peak), which was mainly ascribed to the higher proportion of Co species [45]. Obviously, the proportion of Ⅲ peak was decreased with the addition of K, indicating that K inhibited the reduction degree of Co species. Consequently, the H2-TPR results demonstrated that K doping had a significant effect on adjusting the reduction degree of Co species, while the effect varied with Co/Cu ratio. The selectivity of isomeric alcohols over the K-doped and K-free catalysts was shown in Figs. 9a and 9b. Compared to K-free catalysts, the selectivity of isopropanol and isobutanol over K-doped catalysts was improved. It was confirmed that the addition of alkali metals on the Cu-based catalysts could strengthen C-O dissociation, improving HA selectivity. Furthermore, the isomeric alcohols were main products over the alkali metals promoted Cu-based catalysts [46,47]. Moreover, the C1-C3 alcohol of K-Co1Cu4/KIT-6 and K-Co3Cu2/KIT-6 displayed the “convex” type compared to the K-free catalysts, indicating that methanol formation was inhibited (Figure S3). As reported by our previous work, the promoter-assisted strategy favored to limit the formation of active sites for methanol synthesis, displaying “convex” type [26]. Characterization results confirmed that K doping improved the metal dispersion, thereby strengthening the synergistic effect between Co and Cu species, which was a key factor in forming the “convex” type. However, K doping had a slight effect on the type of C1-C3 alcohol for Co4Cu1/KIT-6. This discrepancy was attributed to the dominance of highly dispersed Co species as active sites with increasing Co content [26]. These results highlighted that the interaction between K and Cu species was another critical factor for the formation of the “convex” type. To eliminate the influence of Co species, the catalytic performance of Cu/KIT-6 and K-Cu/KIT-6 catalysts was conducted (Table S1). Compared with Cu/KIT-6, the CO conversion and HA fraction of K-Cu/KIT-6 were improved from 3.2 % to 7.9 % and 22.3–41.4 %, respectively. The in-situ DRIFT spectra of CO adsorption of Cu/KIT-6 and K-Cu/KIT-6 catalysts was performed in Figs. 9c and 9d. The samples were first in-situ reduced at 400 °C and then exposed to CO flow at 270 °C for 30 min. As shown in Fig. 9c, two absorption bands were performed over the samples at the wavenumber area of 2050 cm−1-2250 cm−1, which corresponded to the gaseous CO on the Cu sites [48]. It was reported that the band of CO absorption on highly dispersed Cu species, interacting strongly with the support or promoters, presented a higher stability than the Cu0 species [49]. Thus, the peak at around 2125 cm−1 corresponded to CO absorption on the highly dispersed Cu. For K-Cu/KIT-6, the peak shifted to lower wavenumber (red shift) and the intensity of the peak became stronger. Generally, the red shift in CO adsorption suggested that the bond of C and O was weakened by the strong interaction of Cu-CO, helping to dissociated the CO [50]. Moreover, the stronger intensity of CO absorption was ascribed to the improved metal dispersion by K as confirmed by the characterization results. The band at 3401 cm−1 was derived from hydroxyl group (OH*) [51]. In Fig. 9d, the intensity of OH* over K-Cu/KIT-6 was stronger than that of Cu/KIT-6, indicating that K improved the surface OH* species. To eliminate the effect of CO, the samples were exposed to Ar at room temperature for several minutes. For all the samples, the CO adsorption peak at the higher value gradually disappeared, while the peak centered at the lower value decreased and eventually stabilized. Notably, the intensity of each CO adsorption peak and OH* over K-Cu/KIT-6 was stronger than Cu/KIT-6. Ang et al. [52] identified that the CO adsorption became stronger over the Cu-based catalysts owing to the OH* . The catalytic performance and the in-situ DRIFT spectra of CO adsorption results of Cu/KIT-6 and K-Cu/KIT-6 confirmed that K doping could enhance the ability of CO adsorption on Cu sites, which had positive effect on carbon growth process. Consequently, the regulating effect of K on Co and Cu species was clear. Results from EIS, TEM and product distribution analysis indicated that K doping improved the metal dispersion, thereby strengthening the synergistic effect between Co and Cu. The Co/Cu ratio played a key role in the influence of K on the Co0/Coδ+ ratio as confirmed by H2-TPR. Additionally, the induced OH* species enhanced the ability of CO adsorption on Cu sites. Thus, the increased Co0/Coδ+ ratio, the improved synergistic effect between Co and Cu and the enhanced ability of CO adsorption on Cu sites collectively contributed to the improved CO conversion and HA selectivity of K-Co1Cu4/KIT-6. In Co-rich catalysts, the decreased Co0/Coδ+ ratio resulted in lower CO conversion, while the improved synergistic effect between Co and Cu and an optimal Co0/Coδ+ ratio attributed to higher HA selectivity. 3.2.6 Effect of K on the reaction stability of the CoCu catalysts The stability test for K-free and K-doped catalysts was conducted and the results were shown in Fig. 10 . In Figs. 10a, 10c and 10e, all the K-free catalysts exhibited the poor reaction stability, in which the CO conversion decreased and the methanol fraction gradually increased during 100 h test. Notably, the CO conversion, HA selectivity and methanol fraction of K-Co1Cu4/KIT-6 catalysts maintained stable at approximately 17.5 %, 17.4 % and 37.1 %, respectively (Fig. 10b). However, the reaction stability of K-doped Co-rich catalysts was not improved. The evolution of Co and Cu species was the main reason as the KIT-6 was not engaged in the reaction [26]. Both the aggregation of Cu and the formation of Co2C had a significant effect on the CO conversion and the product selectivity [12]. Thus, the results demonstrated that K effectively inhibited the evolution of active sites in Cu-rich catalysts. However, the evolution of active sites remained evident in Co-rich catalysts, despite the regulation applied. The ASF distribution of alcohols during the reaction was fitted (Figure S4-S9) and the corresponding α values were calculated and summarized in Fig. 11. The value of (α(C4-C6)-α(C1-C3)) for K-Co1Cu4/KIT-6 maintained stable at approximately 0.29. Nevertheless, the value of Co1Cu4/KIT-6, K-free and K-doped Co-rich catalysts increased continuously. Our previous work demonstrated that the increase in the value of (α(C4-C6)-α(C1-C3)) was attributed to the phase separation of CoCu species [26], which led to an alteration in the Co0/Coδ⁺ ratio and the aggregation of Cu particles [12]. Thus, it was suggested that the addition of K over Co1Cu4 inhibited the aggregation of Cu and the evolution of Co species. To further confirmed this conclusion, the TEM and XPS analysis of the spent catalysts were conducted. As shown in Figure S10a and S10b, the particles of Co1Cu4/KIT-6 aggregated seriously during the reaction. Besides, the large particles displayed an interlayer spacing of 0.209 nm (Figure S10c), which were attributed to the lattice planes of Cu, indicating that the aggregation of particles mainly occurred in Cu species. However, no obvious aggregation of metal particles was observed on K-Co1Cu4/KIT-6 (Figure S10d). It was reported that the OH* derived from K could inhibit the aggregation of Cu species, thereby enhancing the reaction stability [53]. Based on the analyze of CO2-TPD and in-situ DRIFT CO adsorption characterization, K doping provided more OH* species on the catalysts, demonstrating that the poor stability of K-doped Co-rich catalyst was ascribed to the evolution of Co species during reaction. Considering the carburization process of Co species under reaction conditions [54], the XPS study of the spent K-Co4Cu1/KIT-6 was conducted. Compared to the reduced catalysts, the peak for C 1 s shifted to lower BE (from 284.6 eV to 283.8 eV) among the 100 h test, suggesting that the Co2C was formed during reaction [55] (Figure S10e). Meanwhile, the surface concentration of Co0 changed from 7.1 % to 5.3 % (Figure S10f), indicating that the formation of Co2C had a significant effect on Co0/Coδ⁺ ratio. Additionally, Cui et al. [56] suggested that although Co2C and CoO exhibited similar CO insertion capabilities, their catalytic mechanisms were likely distinct. Moreover, large amounts works have confirmed that both Co0 and CoO would transformed to Co2C and the transformation between Co0 and Co2C was bidirectional [57]. However, the works about the transformation from Co2C to CoO under the reaction conditions were rarely reported, implying that the ratio of Co0/CoO was mainly responsible for the evolution of Co species. Combining with the results of H2-TPR and XPS characterization, the increased proportion of CoO was the main reason for the poor stability over Co-rich catalysts. The catalytic performance and reaction stability of K-Co1Cu4/KIT-6 and some representative catalysts were summarized in Table 3. Compared with the Cu-rich catalysts reported in literatures, K-Co1Cu4/KIT-6 was one of the best catalysts for higher alcohol synthesis owing to the higher CO conversion and HA selectivity. Besides, K-Co1Cu4/KIT-6 exhibited the excellent reaction stability compared to the alloy catalysts. Thus, the K-doped strategy played a key role in enhancing both the catalytic performance and reaction stability, providing some guidance for the further development of CoCu catalysts. 4 Conclusion In summary, this work demonstrated that K-doping strategy could stabilize Co and Cu species during the reaction, thereby improving the stability of CoCu catalysts in HA synthesis. With the doping of K, the catalytic performance of all the CoCu catalysts was improved. Especially for Cu-rich catalysts, K doping boosted the total alcohol selectivity from 9.1 % to 17.4 % and reduced methanol fraction from 61.7 % to 37.1 %. The XRD, XPS and CO2-TPD techniques presented that K-doping not only improved metal dispersion, but also adjusted the Co0/Coδ⁺ ratio and provided OH* group. As evidenced by the EIS and TEM results, K-doping enhanced the electrical conductivity of the catalysts, improving the metal dispersion during the reduction process. The H2-TPR results indicated that the ratio of Co0/Coδ⁺ was increased in K-doped Cu-rich catalysts owing to the hydrogen spillover, which the opposite trend occurred on Co-rich catalysts. More importantly, the in-situ DRIFT CO adsorption results suggested that the interaction between OH* and Cu species reinforced the CO adsorption ability of Cu species, facilitating the HA formation. Thus, the improved CO conversion of Cu-rich catalysts (from 10.3 % to 17.5 %) was ascribed to the enhanced Co0 and OH* species. Besides, the analyze of alcohol distribution combined with TEM and XPS results provided a direct information that the K-induced OH* restrained the aggregation of Cu species and the higher proportion of Co0 mitigated the impact of Co evolution. As a result, K-doped Cu-rich catalysts achieved an excellent stability during 100 h test, while Co-rich catalysts (Co/Cu =3:2 and 4:1) exhibited performance fluctuations due to the evolution of Co species to Co2C. This work highlighted the critical interplay between promoter effects and intrinsic bimetallic phase behavior and provided more guidance for further design and fabrication of highly stable bimetallic catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Developing the stable CoCu catalysts for higher alcohol (HA) synthesis is hindered by the dynamic evolution of complex active sites. Herein, a potassium (K)-modified strategy was proposed to address these issues. The regulating effect of K on Co and Cu sites was comprehensively explored. K doping not only enhanced the metal dispersion, but also regulated the Co0/Coδ⁺ ratio and provided the hydroxyl groups (OH*). The enhanced metal dispersion was ascribed to the improved electrical conductivity, strengthening the synergistic effect. The Co0 proportion of Cu-rich catalysts increased, while it decreased over Co-rich catalysts. The K-induced OH* enhanced CO adsorption ability of Cu species, improving HA selectivity and restraining the aggregation of Cu species. The higher Co0 proportion mitigated the impact of Co evolution. Hence, K doping Cu-rich catalysts boosted total alcohol selectivity from 9.1 % to 17.4 %, reduced methanol fraction from 61.7 % to 37.1 %, and achieved excellent stability during 100 h test.
